questions.question_text:
A network engineer must implement SNMPv2 with these parameters:
✑ Enable SNMP community string c1sc0 with read-only permissions.
✑ Enable interface index persistence.
Restrict the SNMP community to only the monitoring server with IP address 198.18.19.100/32.
//IMG//

✑ Provide view-only access to ospfIfEntry and ospfNbrEntry.
Which configuration must the engineer apply?

choices.D: configure terminal access-list 5 permit 198.18.19.100 0.0.0.0 snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW internet excluded snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfIfEntry included snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfNbrEntry included snmp-server community c1sc0 view BLOCKED_VIEW RW 5 snmp ifmib ifindex persist end
choices.B: configure terminal access-list 5 permit 198.18.19.100 0.0.0.0 snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW internet excluded snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfIfEntry included snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfNbrEntry included snmp-server community c1sc0 view BLOCKED_VIEW RO 5 snmp ifmib ifindex persist end
choices.A: configure terminal access-list 5 permit 198.18.19.100 0.0.0.0 snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW internet excluded snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfIfEntry included snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfNbrEntry included snmp-server community c1sc0 view BLOCKED_VIEW RO snmp ifmib ifindex persist end
choices.C: configure terminal access-list 5 permit 198.18.19.100 0.0.0.0 snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW internet included snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfIfEntry included snmp-server view BLOCKED_VIEW ospfNbrEntry included snmp-server community c1sc0 view BLOCKED_VIEW RO snmp ifmib ifindex persist end

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
snmp-server view BlOCKED_VIEW internet excluded
snmp-server view BlOCKED_VIEW ospfIfEntry included
snmp-server view BlOCKED_VIEW ospfNbrEntry included
snmp-server community c1sc0 view BLOCKED_VIEW RO 5
snmp ifmib ifindex persist
B - need RO 5
B is correct

B
- RO
- excluded
- 5 (mention of ACL is a must)

The Answer is B, but the wording of this question is bad.
Serial links default to P2P OSPF network type while a ethernet will default to broadcast. Both of the peers would become fully adjacent, but would have issues after the SPF calculation.. 
My first instinct was different encapsulations, and internetworking wasn't configured correctly, but this is ONLY a CE question. We must assume the Provide network is setup perfectly

The correct answer is B.
Why? First, In the question it clearly says that you have to assume the AToM is configured correctly.
Secondly, clearly you see that the network type is not specified and the default types for ethernet is broadcast with DR whereas serial is point-to-point, these don't match.

Selected Answer: B
D cannot be correct because it is stated that the configuration is on the CEs. The CEs on an L2VPN implementation will not have any xconnect configuration since they are agnostic to the transport that connects them. The OSPF adjacency between the two will not work because the default OSPF network type is different on a fastethernet and a serial interface.

You need loopback to be configure in CE, so Answer is C
https://community.cisco.com/t5/service-providers-knowledge-base/configuration-example-atom-any-transport-over-mpls-for-like-to/ta-p/3144810

Selected Answer: B
Sorry, my previous understanding is wrong.
Here, CE routers, and it doesn't do anything with xconnect; only PE does xconnect. Hence, D is wrong.
OSPF works with L2VPN, hence A is wrong.

OSPF can't build neighbour adjacency if there is a network type mismatch; hence, the correct answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
Agree with "sushil_bhattacharjee". Correct Answer should be "D".

Selected Answer: D
For instance, it looks like [CE1<-->PE1<-->P1<-->P2<-->PE2<-->CE2]
A. is not correct. Since OSPF works with L2VPN
B. There is no neighbourship in between CE1 and CE2, rather it is CE1 with PE1 and CE2 with PE2. 
C. It is not mandatory to add loopback. So it is not correct.
D. It requires to add the "xconnect" command under the interface in CE rotuers which are missing in the display. It requires to add under the interface command in the CE1 and CE2 "Router(config)# interface <interface-type>/<interface-number>
Router(config-if)# xconnect <peer-address> <vc-id> encapsulation mpls".
Therefore, Answer D is correct, in my opinion.

Selected Answer: B
Both network types should be same

I think the correct answer is D.
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios/12_4t/mpls/configuration/guide/tpseudo.html#wp1054177

comments.content: The Xconnect statement is required on the PE interface that faces the CE, both configurations shown are of CE routers, so Xconnect statement would not be relevant.

choices.C: A loopback with a /32 IP address has not been used.
choices.A: OSPF does not work with L2VPN services.
choices.D: The xconnect statement has not been defined.
choices.B: The routing protocol network types are not compatible.
snmp-server enable traps bgp snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public
choices.A: snmp-server enable traps entity snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public
choices.C: snmp-server enable traps isdn snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public
choices.D: snmp-server enable traps snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public

comments.content:
The question is: Which configuration must the engineer apply so that all traps are sent to the new server?

A, B and C are sending particular traps, not all traps, so these options are not correct.

discussion.content:
snmp-server enable traps entity: This command enables SNMP traps related to the "entity" notification group. The "entity" group includes notifications related to changes in the physical and logical entities of the device, such as modules, interfaces, and system components.

snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public: This command specifies the SNMP trap destination host and community string. In this case, it sets the trap destination to the IP address 192.168.1.2, and the community string used for trap notifications is "public."

Selected Answer: D
If you don't specify which traps, you get all traps with this command

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/13506-snmp-traps.html#:~:text=Commands-,The%20%20snmp%2Dserver%20host%20%20Command,-Issue%20the%20%20snmp

 snmp-server enable traps snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public

comments.content:
yes right , 
snmp-server enable traps----------enable all traps 
snmp-server host 192.168.1.2 public----send traps to destination

discussion.content: doubting entity option could be the right one ... pls share experience if any one used it already

questions.question_text: A network administrator must monitor network usage to provide optimal performance to the network end users when the network is under heavy load. The administrator asked the engineer to install a new server to receive SNMP traps at destination 192.168.1.2. Which configuration must the engineer apply so that all traps are sent to the new server?
What must a network engineer consider when designing a Cisco MPLS TE solution with OSPF?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Only needs to be enabled on all routers that will handle traffic engineered paths. As long as area 1 is not a stub(by) area it should work.

Selected Answer: A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/iosxr/ncs5xx/mpls/65x/b-mpls-cg-65x-ncs540/cg_65_implementing_mpls_traffic_engineering.pdf

"
MPLS-TE requires co-ordination among several global neighbor routers. RSVP, MPLS-TE and IGP are configured on all routers and interfaces in the MPLS traffic engineering network. Explicit path and TE tunnel interfaces are configured only on the head-end routers
"

choices.B: OSPF extensions for RSVP-TE are supported in Area 1.
choices.A: The OSPF extensions and RSVP-TE must be enabled on all routers in the network.
choices.C: The OSPF extensions and RSVP-TE must be enabled on the egress routers.
choices.D: OSPF extensions for RSVP-TE are implemented in Type 6, 7, and 8 LSAs.
